ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Reading literary chinese, introduction to chinese literature, philosophy and history. Reading and using Chinese databases available at Yale and abroad!
A great appreciation for literary Chinese and the usage of dictionaries for translation.

I not only learned 1000+ new vocabulary words, many new grammar constructions, and how to use Chinese databases, but I also developed a keen understanding of the classical Chinese canonical philosophical texts: Kongzi, Laozi, Zhuangzi, Xunzi, the Shanhaijing, Qing Dynasty memorials, the Mulan poem in the original, Buddhist sutras, etc. So much.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is very well structured, and Prof Lin is very good at summarizing key learnings points and reinforcing them through tests and quizzes. Prof Lin is also excellent at making a wonderful class dynamic. I was so surprised to grow so close to my classmates especially due to the pandemic and virtual nature of the class, but Prof Lin really fostered a sense of community of eager and avid learners! I really felt like I was in one of those ancient Chinese classrooms (or my historically-inaccurate imaginations of them), where I could study with friends who also love studying!

STRENGTHS: Dr. P/Professor Lin is the kindest person ever. Mick Hunter is absolute garbage and should not be allowed to teach whereas Dr. P should be given all of the awards. All of them. Give her everything. The kindest person at Yale. WEAK: quizzes are way too long, midterm way too much is asked of you, final project took forever, class got a little monotonous, never had enough time for anything and always went over. But what a colossal improvement from the sh*tshow that was CHNS 170.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The use of collaborative Google Doc was actually very effective in getting the students in class to mingle and speak up to share their work! I did not expect it to be such a good medium, given how confusing Google Doc can be, but I am glad it worked out!
breakout rooms and shared docs were fantastic. I loved the use of the PPT in every class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! If you are interested in literary Chinese, please take this class. It is life-changing, and you don't even know it yet. The exposure into Chinese literature and thought is particularly good, also because as part of translation, one reads the text extremely slowly  which honestly deepens understanding far more than if one is taking a not-translation class!
Yes, if you enjoy literary Chinese and the translation process.
Absolutely. Dr. P is great and tailors the class to your own needs.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

CHNS 571 01/CHNS 171 01
